questions.explanation: This sign indicates that U-turns are prohibited. You may see a sign like this at an intersection that commonly has oncoming traffic.

questions.question: While driving, you come upon a sign displaying the words “Reduced speed, 35 mph." This means:
questions.answerA: That the new 35 mph speed limit begins at this sign.
questions.answerB: That the new 35 mph speed limit begins at the next speed limit sign.
questions.answerC: That you have plenty of time to slow down before the reduced speed zone.
questions.answerD: That you should reduce your speed to 35 mph, but only under poor weather conditions.
questions.explanation: "Reduced speed" signs inform drivers that they must reduce their speeds. If a new speed limit is posted on one of these signs, the new speed limit begins at the sign.

questions.question: When driving on an interstate:
questions.answerA: Stop on the shoulder of the road if you are tired.
questions.answerB: You should always use cruise control.
questions.answerC: Signal, check mirrors, and check blind spots before changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Signal, check your mirrors, and check your blind spot before changing lanes or passing on an interstate. Only stop on the shoulder of the interstate in the case of an emergency and change lanes as infrequently as possible. Cruise control should not be used in heavy traffic or under poor weather conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about blind spots is true?
questions.answerA: They are eliminated if you have one outside mirror on each side of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Large trucks have bigger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blind spots can be checked by looking in your rearview mirrors.
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas that a driver cannot see if they look in their mirrors. Large trucks have large blind spots that drivers of other vehicles should avoid.

questions.question: If a truck or bus is making a right turn where you also need to make a right turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn before the truck or bus is able to.
questions.answerB: Wait until the truck or bus turns before you turn.
questions.answerC: Squeeze between the truck or bus and the curb.
questions.explanation: If you try to insert your vehicle between a turning truck or bus and a curb, you may suffer a serious crash. To avoid a collision, do not turn until the truck or bus has completed its turn.

questions.question: Seat belts are most effective when they are worn by:
questions.answerB: Passengers when they are on a long drive.
questions.answerC: All occupants of a car being driven on an expressway.
questions.answerD: All occupants of a car every time the car is driven.
questions.explanation: When you drive, make sure each person in your vehicle wears a seat belt. In the event of a crash, a person without a seat belt becomes a flying object and a danger to each person in the vehicle.

questions.question: What message will be found on a red octagon-shaped sign?
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: An octagonal (eight-sided) sign always means "stop." You must always come to a complete stop at this sign.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrians walking along the road ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians must not cross here.
questions.answerD: Be alert for construction workers on the road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates the presence of a pedestrian crossing. Drivers should be cautious when driving where pedestrians may be present.

questions.question: You can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by:
questions.answerA: Driving 10 mph faster than the car behind you.
questions.answerB: Driving 10 mph slower than the car behind you.
questions.answerC: Maintaining a steady speed.
questions.explanation: It is not always easy to maintain a safe distance behind your vehicle. However, you can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by maintaining a steady speed and signaling turns, lane changes, and deceleration in advance.

questions.question: You see pedestrians near the road. You should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn and maintain your speed.
questions.answerB: Speed up to clear the area quickly.
questions.answerC: Slow down and pass with caution.
questions.explanation: Watch for any pedestrian who may cross your path. If you see pedestrians near the road where you are driving, slow down and be prepared to stop, if necessary.

questions.question: Allow extra space in front of your vehicle when following a:
questions.answerB: Passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: Motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Allow for extra space when driving behind a motorcycle. Motorcycles can stop more quickly than other vehicles can and you must have adequate room to stop if the motorcyclist brakes or falls off. Also, remember that motorcycles are difficult to see at night because they only have one tail light.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerB: Road curve.
questions.answerC: Right turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that another road crosses the highway ahead.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Winding road.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates a low ground railroad crossing. Where this sign is present, railroad tracks cross the road at a steep slope and the bottom of low vehicles may drag or get caught on the tracks.

questions.question: The “No zone” is:
questions.answerA: A term used to describe blind spots around a truck or bus.
questions.answerB: A special speed zone.
questions.answerC: A roadway with restrictions on vehicle stereo volume.
questions.answerD: The television show that replaced The Twilight Zone.
questions.explanation: A truck or bus has blind spots on each side, in the rear, and in the front. An automobile cannot be seen in these blind spots. These blind spots are referred to as the “No zone.”

questions.question: When driving in fog:
questions.answerB: Use your low beams.
questions.answerC: Use your high beams.
questions.answerD: It makes no difference which lights you use.
questions.explanation: You should use low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow.

questions.question: You experience an incident at work that has left you feeling angry. When you get to your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Play the radio loudly so you won’t think about it.
questions.answerB: Drive fast on the interstate to let off steam.
questions.answerC: Take a few minutes to cool off before you begin your drive home.
questions.answerD: Stop at your favorite bar and have a few drinks before driving home.
questions.explanation: Persons who are upset, angry, or otherwise distracted by their emotions should take time to cool off before driving a car. Taking out frustrations or anger while driving is exercising very poor judgment and is very dangerous to both the driver and others on the road.

questions.question: Remove all snow, frost, and ice from:
questions.answerB: All windows.
questions.answerC: Just the windshield and passenger window.
questions.explanation: It is important that you are able to see clearly through all of your vehicle's windows, including the windshield. Remove all snow, ice, and frost from your vehicle's windows and mirrors before you start to drive.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection with a flashing red light. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Slow down and drive carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop, check the traffic, and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to other traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when it safe to do so.

questions.question: If you have trouble seeing other vehicles because of dust or smoke blowing across the roadway, you should drive more slowly and turn on your:
questions.answerB: Parking lights.
questions.answerC: Headlights.
questions.explanation: You must turn on your headlights any time conditions prevent you from seeing other vehicles. Other drivers may have trouble seeing you, too.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerB: Road curve.
questions.answerC: Right turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that an intersection with a crossing road is ahead.

questions.question: Your first response to reduced visibility should be:
questions.answerB: Reducing your speed.
questions.answerC: Turning on your windshield wipers.
questions.answerD: Looking for road edge markings to guide you.
questions.explanation: Reducing your speed should be your first response to decreased visibility and dangerous road conditions.

questions.question: If moving with a stream of vehicles across a railroad track, it is safe to stop on the track for a short period of time.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: It is prohibited to stop, stand, or park on a railroad track. You should never cross railroad tracks unless there is room for your entire vehicle on the other side of tracks.

questions.question: Defensive driving is:
questions.answerB: Using safe driving strategies to prevent crashes.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than not driving defensively.
questions.explanation: Defensive driving is using safe driving strategies to prevent crashes. This means that you alter your driving to fit the weather conditions, the way you feel, and the actions of other drivers, bicyclists, and pedestrians.

questions.question: You hit a parked vehicle and can't find the owner. What must you do?
questions.answerA: Call your insurance company when you get home.
questions.answerB: Wait for the owner to return.
questions.answerC: Leave a note with your name and address on the parked vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you hit a parked vehicle or other property, you must leave a note with your name, phone number, and address securely attached to the vehicle or property that you hit.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway ends.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that the divided highway is about to end.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You can travel in either direction in this lane.
questions.answerB: There is two-way traffic.
questions.answerC: You are approaching a divided highway.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of two-way traffic.

questions.question: A good rule to remember for passing is:
questions.answerA: Pass on the right whenever possible.
questions.answerB: Drive with the flow of traffic and pass only as needed.
questions.answerC: Try to get to the front of any slow-moving traffic so that you can see better.
questions.answerD: Always flash your lights and sound your horn to alert other drivers to your intentions.
questions.explanation: Each time you pass another vehicle, there is an increased chance for a collision. If you are moving faster than surrounding traffic, you will have to continue passing others. Drive with the flow of traffic, within the legal speed limit, and pass only as needed.

questions.question: Yellow lines separate:
questions.answerB: Traffic moving in opposite directions on two-way roads.
questions.answerC: All carpool lanes from regular traffic lanes.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines mark the center of a road used for two-way traffic. A solid yellow centerline indicates that drivers may not cross the line to pass. A broken yellow centerline indicates that drivers may cross the line to pass, but only if passing would not interfere with traffic.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street the wrong way.
questions.answerB: School crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Do not drive in this lane.
questions.answerD: Traffic turning left on the green light must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: This sign is used with a traffic signal to tell drivers that left-turning traffic does not have the right-of-way and must instead wait for oncoming traffic to clear.

questions.question: You must stop at a railroad crossing when:
questions.answerA: Directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerB: It is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign. Stop when flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.

questions.question: Stress can affect your driving by:
questions.answerA: Lowing your ability to focus on driving.
questions.answerB: Decreasing your chances of an accident.
questions.answerC: Causing you to fall asleep at the wheel.
questions.answerD: Making you more aware of others around you.
questions.explanation: Emotions can have a great effect on your driving ability. You may not be able to drive well if you are overly worried, excited, afraid, angry, or sad. Stress can lessen your concentration on the task of driving. It is better to wait to drive than to risk driving while you are emotionally unstable.

questions.question: Motorcycles are entitled to:
questions.answerB: The same full lane width as other motor vehicles.
questions.answerC: Half the width of a lane.
questions.explanation: Lane usage for the motorcyclist is critical. Motorcycles are entitled to the same full lane width as all other vehicles.

questions.question: On a road which has no sidewalks, a pedestrian should walk on the:
questions.answerA: Side of the road which has the lightest traffic.
questions.answerB: Same side of the road on which traffic is moving.
questions.answerC: Side of the road facing oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Side of the road which has the heaviest traffic.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians should walk on the side of the road facing the traffic in the lane nearest them.

questions.question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that:
questions.answerA: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the solid yellow line.
questions.answerB: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the broken yellow line.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow line alongside a solid yellow line means that traffic in the lane next to the broken line may cross the line to pass, while traffic in the lane next to the solid line may not.

questions.question: When driving on roads that may be slippery:
questions.answerA: Always drive at the maximum speed limit.
questions.answerB: Use cruise control to maintain a steady speed.
questions.answerC: Reduce your following distance.
questions.answerD: Do not make any sudden changes in speed or direction.
questions.explanation: You should avoid making any sudden changes in speed or direction when driving on a slippery surface. Reduce your speed on slippery roads and do not use cruise control.

questions.question: Which of the following commonly causes traffic accidents?
questions.answerB: Excessive speed under the driving conditions
questions.answerC: Following other vehicles too closely
questions.explanation: Driving too fast for conditions is a major cause of motor vehicle crashes. Being inattentive to surroundings can cause a driver to collide with other vehicles. Most rear-end collisions are caused by drivers following other vehicles too closely.

questions.question: When preparing to make a left turn from a two-way street, you should drive:
questions.answerA: Near the right-hand side of the road.
questions.answerB: Near the centerline.
questions.answerC: On the left of the centerline.
questions.explanation: When you are turning left from a two-way street, begin in the lane closest to the centerline and start your turn just before the front of your car reaches the center of the intersection. Do not cut the corner. Steering hand-over-hand, turn into the first available legal lane.

questions.question: When you see this road sign, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep left.
questions.answerC: Pass with caution.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that a divided highway is beginning and cars should keep to the right.

questions.question: A yellow and black diamond-shaped sign:
questions.answerA: Warns you about conditions on or near the road.
questions.answerB: Helps direct you to cities and towns ahead.
questions.answerC: Tells you about traffic laws and regulations.
questions.answerD: Tells you about road construction ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs, which tell you about conditions on or near the road ahead, are usually diamond-shaped with black symbols or words on a yellow background.

questions.question: When a pedestrian guided by a dog or carrying a white cane is crossing the street:
questions.answerA: You must always yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: You must tell them where to cross the street.
questions.answerC: You only have to yield the right-of-way if you are at a corner.
questions.explanation: Blind or partially blind pedestrians may carry a white cane or use the assistance of a guide dog. You must always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian who is using a guide dog or carrying a white cane.

questions.question: What should you do when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Look for a train station ahead.
questions.answerB: Signal before going any further.
questions.answerC: Slow down and yield to trains.
questions.explanation: A round sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing. This sign is posted a few hundred feet in front of the tracks and tells drivers to slow down, look, listen, and prepare to stop.

questions.question: A seat belt should be adjusted so that it:
questions.answerB: Is buckled snugly across your hip bones and lower abdomen.
questions.answerC: Is hidden beneath the seat.
questions.answerD: Keeps the seat belt buzzer or light from operating.
questions.explanation: Lap belts should fit snugly across your hip bones and the lower part of your abdomen. Shoulder belts should sit comfortably so that you can insert your fist between the belt and your chest.

questions.question: To check your blind spot when changing lanes to the left, you should glance:
questions.answerB: At your side mirror.
questions.answerC: Over your left shoulder.
questions.explanation: To check your blind spot, glance over your shoulder in the direction that you want to move.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that there is a steep hill ahead. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.

questions.question: Which of the following are factors commonly contributing to traffic crashes?
questions.answerA: Exceeding the posted speed limit and driving too fast for conditions or circumstances.
questions.answerB: Getting adequate rest and staying alert.
questions.answerC: Scanning the environment and staying focused on the driving task.
questions.explanation: Driving above the speed limit, driving too far below the speed limit, and driving too fast for conditions are all actions that commonly contribute to traffic accidents. Always drive with the general flow of traffic, within legal speed limits.

questions.question: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest you can drive in an area.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest legal driving speed in an area, under ideal conditions. You must reduce your speed when conditions require it, such as when the roadway is slippery or when it is difficult to see clearly down the road.

questions.question: If two drivers arrive at the same time to an open intersection:
questions.answerA: The driver on the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The driver on the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: One driver may continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerD: One driver should honk to indicate that they are giving up the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: If you arrive to an open intersection at the same time as a vehicle to your right, you should yield the right-of-way to that vehicle. You may then proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Drivers may park in the handicap parking access aisles located directly beside handicap parking stalls.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: It is prohibited for anyone to park in handicap parking access aisles. These aisles are meant to provide space for wheelchairs and wheelchair lifts.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should return to your original lane when:
questions.answerA: You can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: You have cleared the front bumper of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerC: You are 50 feet in front of the passed vehicle.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle, move back into your original lane only when you can see the passed vehicle’s headlights in your rearview mirror. This ensures that you will have enough room to safely pull back in front of the other vehicle.

questions.question: A red arrow displayed on a traffic light means that:
questions.answerA: A driver must proceed slowly through the intersection.
questions.answerB: A driver must stop and then proceed when the way is clear.
questions.answerC: A driver must stop and then proceed when the signal changes to a green light or green arrow.
questions.answerD: A driver may turn in the direction that the red arrow is pointing.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign indicates otherwise, a traffic signal displaying a red arrow means that drivers must come to a full stop and remain stopped until a green light or green arrow appears.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerB: Red, green, yellow.
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.explanation: On a traffic signal arranged vertically, red is always on top and green on the bottom. When arranged horizontally, red is always on the left and green on the right.

questions.question: The effect that lack of sleep has on your safe driving ability is the same as:
questions.answerB: The effect that amphetamines have.
questions.answerC: The effect that anger has.
questions.answerD: The effect that driving with teenagers has.
questions.explanation: Fatigue and being under the influence of alcohol have similar effects on your ability to drive safely. For example, being awake for 18 hours impairs your driving about as much as a blood alcohol level of 0.05 percent. Being awake for 24 hours in a row has the same effect on your driving as a blood alcohol level of 0.10 percent.

questions.question: You have allowed the wheels of your vehicle to run off the edge of the pavement. What should you do first?
questions.answerA: Turn the front wheels slightly to the left to edge the car back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes and turn the front wheels sharply to the left.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle leaves the roadway, hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes. Wait until your speed has reduced, check the traffic, and look for a place to safely return to the roadway by merging back into traffic. Overcompensating by jerking the wheel to return to the roadway can cause you to lose control of your vehicle or may cause your car to go into other lanes of traffic.

questions.question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop before entering the intersection.
questions.answerB: Yield just to the traffic on the right.
questions.answerC: Yield just to the traffic on the left.
questions.answerD: Slow down and yield the right-of-way to other traffic.
questions.explanation: A yield sign means that you must slow down and yield the right-of-way to traffic in the intersection or roadway you are entering.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway starts.
questions.answerC: Divided highway ends.
questions.explanation: This sign warns drivers that the divided highway ends ahead.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Cross the centerline in an intersection.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spots by looking over your left or right shoulder.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check for drivers trying to pass you who may be trying to enter the same lane as you. Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. You should never attempt to pass or otherwise change lanes in an intersection.

questions.question: You exit the freeway on a ramp that curves downhill. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow to a safe speed before the curve.
questions.answerB: Slow to the posted speed limit for the freeway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you have entered the curve to begin braking.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down before entering a curve. You may not be able to see hazards ahead and braking in a curve may cause your vehicle to skid.

questions.question: You are waiting to turn left at a multilane intersection and opposing traffic is blocking your view. You should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate rapidly when the first lane you need to cross is clear.
questions.answerB: Wait until you can see all the lanes you need to cross before going ahead with your turn.
questions.answerC: Wait for an oncoming driver to wave you across the intersection.
questions.answerD: Edge your car into each lane of opposing traffic as soon as it clears.
questions.explanation: You should never start a left turn until you can see that all the lanes you need to cross are clear and that you can safely make the turn.

questions.question: When changing lanes you should not:
questions.answerA: Check your side and rearview mirrors.
questions.answerB: Give a turn signal to signal your intentions.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers who may be moving into the same lane as you.
questions.answerD: Use your cell phone to contact the police to determine if the road ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check your side and rearview mirrors for traffic approaching you from behind. Use your turn signal to let other drivers know you plan to change lanes. Check for other drivers who also may be moving into the same lane.

questions.question: As you near an intersection, the traffic light changes from green to yellow. Your best action is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes sharply to stop.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop in the center of the intersection.
questions.answerD: Be prepared to stop before the intersection.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow traffic light indicates that the light will soon change to red. You should be prepared to stop for the red light, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: On a freeway, you realize you missed your turn or exit. You should:
questions.answerA: Make the turn quickly from your lane of travel.
questions.answerB: Stop and back up.
questions.answerC: Continue driving until you reach the next turn, exit, or other location where you can safely turn around.
questions.answerD: Signal other drivers to stop so you can turn.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up, but go on to the next turn or exit where you can safely turn around. It is illegal to back up on a shoulder or a freeway.

questions.question: You are driving at night and another vehicle is approaching from the opposite direction. Your headlights:
questions.answerA: Should be on their high beam setting.
questions.answerB: Should be on their low beam setting.
questions.answerC: Should be off. Use your parking lights.
questions.answerD: May be on either their high or low beam setting.
questions.explanation: Do not use your high beam headlights when approaching or following another vehicle at night. Switch to the low beam setting to ensure the safety of everyone on the road.

questions.question: You may text while driving:
questions.answerA: If you can text without looking at your phone.
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: If you are using a voice-to-text feature.
questions.answerD: If you only look away from the road for a moment.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving in Rhode Island is prohibited. Using a cellular telephone while driving is a major distraction to the operator of a motor vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Flagger ahead.
questions.answerC: Lane ends.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming intersection.

questions.question: It is dangerous to follow a motorcycle too closely because:
questions.answerA: They do not follow the same rules as motor vehicles.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle can stop much faster than a standard vehicle.
questions.answerC: They brake more slowly than motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles can stop quickly and following them too closely endangers your life and that of the motorcyclist. If the motorcyclist makes a mistake, you need to have enough time and space to avoid a crash.

questions.question: When parallel parking, you should park within ____ of the curb.
questions.answerB: 12 inches
questions.answerC: 18 inches
questions.explanation: When parallel parking your vehicle, your wheels should be parallel to and within 12 inches of the curb. Only park where you will not be disruptive to traffic and where other drivers can clearly see your vehicle from every direction.

questions.question: Drivers are required to use their turn signals when leaving a parking space.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: The law states that a driver has to make a signal by hand or by using directional lights when driving out of a parking space. Communicate with other drivers to avoid crashes.

questions.question: The most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of being injured or killed in a traffic crash is to:
questions.answerB: Limit your driving to weekdays.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane on multilane highways.
questions.answerD: Limit your driving to hours between 3:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m.
questions.explanation: Wearing your seat belt is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of death or injury while driving.

questions.question: When driving under icy or snowy conditions, which driving technique will help drivers avoid crashes?
questions.answerA: Add extra weight to their vehicles to improve traction.
questions.answerB: Get off the highways as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Engage the four-wheel drive on their vehicles.
questions.answerD: Reduce their speed and increase their following distance.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when roads are snow-covered or icy. Doing this and increasing your following distance are the most important techniques for avoiding crashes under snowy or icy conditions.

questions.question: Blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on each of the following, except:
questions.answerB: How much you drink.
questions.answerC: How much time passes between drinks.
questions.explanation: Your blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on how much alcohol you drink, how much time passes between drinks, and your weight. It is not affected by the type of alcoholic beverages you drink, your level of physical fitness, or how well you can "hold your liquor."

questions.question: When approaching an intersection controlled by a flashing yellow light, you must:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop at the intersection.
questions.answerB: Maintain your normal speed.
questions.answerC: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow light indicates that you should be alert and proceed with caution. Slow down when approaching a flashing yellow traffic signal.

questions.question: If driving in fog, a driver should turn on the high beam headlights to increase their field of vision.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: While it is not advisable to drive in fog, if you must drive in foggy conditions, you should drive with the headlights set on dim or use fog lights.

questions.question: Where is it safe to pass another vehicle?
questions.answerA: Within an intersection where there are no oncoming vehicles
questions.answerB: Wherever signs and/or pavement markings permit passing
questions.answerC: Within a curve where there are no oncoming vehicles
questions.explanation: Never pass within intersections or at other intersecting points, such as parking lot entrances and alleyways. Any time your view is blocked by a curve or a hill, you should stay in your lane and assume that there is an oncoming vehicle just out of sight. Wherever signs and/or pavement markings permit passing other vehicles, you will have to determine whether or not you have enough space to pass in a safe manner.

questions.question: The best way to avoid a dangerous situation while driving is to:
questions.answerA: Know what is happening around your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Turn off the radio.
questions.answerC: Always keep your eyes focused ahead of your car.
questions.explanation: Always be aware of what is happening around your vehicle. Constantly observing your surroundings to the front, sides, and rear of your vehicle will help you see problems that may require you to change speed or roadway position.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about blind spots is true?
questions.answerA: Blind spots are eliminated if you have one outside mirror.
questions.answerB: Large trucks have bigger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blind spots can be checked by looking in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Even if a vehicle is properly equipped with rearview and outside mirrors, it still has blind spots that cannot be seen in the mirrors. Large trucks have much larger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: End of construction zone.
questions.answerC: School crossing ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a flagger ahead controlling traffic in a construction area.

questions.question: Motorcycles, scooters, and mopeds are not easy to see; therefore, you should:
questions.answerB: Make constant visual checks.
questions.answerC: Share a lane with a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles can be easily hidden in a vehicle’s blind spot or missed in a quick look due to their small size. Drivers of cars must always be alert and looking for motorcycles, mopeds, and scooters.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about roadwork zones?
questions.answerA: Fines are the same for violations committed in work zones as they are under normal traffic conditions.
questions.answerB: You must "Slow for the Cone Zone."
questions.answerC: Slow down only if you think workers are present.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed and be prepared to slow down or stop for highway equipment. Driving carefully through work zones improves safety for drivers, pedestrians, bicyclists, and road workers.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane shifting.
questions.answerC: Low clearance.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they may encounter traffic coming from the opposite direction.

questions.question: The best way to avoid hydroplaning is to:
questions.answerB: Slow down when roads are wet or slushy.
questions.answerC: Watch out for standing water or puddles.
questions.explanation: When roads are wet, cars take a longer distance to stop and may skid on quick turns. Do not use cruise control when driving under wet or icy conditions. Reduce your speed and drive with caution.

questions.question: You may cross solid yellow lines:
questions.answerA: To pass traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerB: During daylight hours only.
questions.answerC: At any time.
questions.explanation: As a general rule, broken traffic lines may be crossed but solid lines may not. Solid yellow lines may be crossed only when the driver is making a turn.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead curves right. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerC: Merge. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerD: Winding road ahead. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.explanation: These signs indicate that the road curves to the right ahead and that drivers should slow down to the safe speed indicated (in this case, 35 mph).

questions.question: Another driver is trying to pass your car. You should:
questions.answerB: Signal to the other driver when it is safe for them to pass.
questions.answerC: Check for oncoming traffic and adjust your speed to allow safe passing.
questions.explanation: Keep right when another driver begins to pass you on the left. Check for oncoming traffic and adjust your speed to let the passing vehicle move back into the right lane as easily as possible.

questions.question: To improve visibility lowered by rain or fog, drivers should use their:
questions.answerB: High beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Parking lights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used when driving in rainy or foggy weather. Even if they do little to help you see, low beams will make it easier for others to see you.

questions.question: You should not start across an intersection if you know you will block the intersection when the light turns red:
questions.answerB: Unless you entered the intersection on a yellow light.
questions.answerC: Unless you entered the intersection on a green light.
questions.explanation: Even if the signal is green, you must not enter an intersection unless you can get completely across before the light turns red. If you block the intersection, you can be cited.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a safe driving practice when driving on the interstate?
questions.answerA: Slower traffic must keep to the right.
questions.answerB: Change lanes without signaling.
questions.answerC: If you miss your exit, you must go to the next exit.
questions.explanation: You should always signal when moving your vehicle to the right or left. On an interstate, you should stay in the right lane if you are moving more slowly than the surrounding traffic. It is illegal to back up or make a U-turn on interstate highways, so if you miss your exit, you should proceed to the next exit.

questions.question: The consumption of alcohol while taking drugs can:
questions.answerA: Decrease the effects of the drugs and alcohol.
questions.answerB: Increase the effects of both the drugs and alcohol.
questions.answerC: Help cure your illness.
questions.explanation: The combination of alcohol and drugs, in some cases, can increase the effects of both the drugs and alcohol. It can be unsafe to drive after consuming either alcohol or drugs and is even more dangerous after combining them.

questions.question: You should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead when you:
questions.answerA: Are following a small passenger vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are being tailgated by another driver.
questions.answerC: Are driving more slowly than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: When being tailgated, create extra space in front of your vehicle and do not brake suddenly. Slow down gradually or merge into another lane to prevent a collision with the tailgater.

questions.question: A traffic light displaying a green arrow and a red light means that:
questions.answerA: You may only drive straight ahead.
questions.answerB: You may drive only in the direction of the green arrow.
questions.answerC: You must wait for a solid green light to proceed in any direction.
questions.answerD: Vehicles moving in any direction must stop.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow is shown with a red light, you can only drive in the direction of the arrow and only if the intersection is clear.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: When pavement is wet, reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds in a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerC: Traffic increases ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the roadway will be slippery when wet and they should reduce their speed accordingly.

questions.question: You may drive in a High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lane if:
questions.answerA: You are driving faster than the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: You are driving more slowly than the flow of traffic.
questions.answerC: Your vehicle has multiple occupants.
questions.answerD: You are trying to get somewhere quickly.
questions.explanation: Some highways reserve the left lane for vehicles with multiple occupants. These High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes are identified by signs and diamond pavement symbols.

questions.question: When a traffic signal light turns green, you should:
questions.answerB: Accelerate as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Back up slowly.
questions.answerD: Not move until another driver waves you on.
questions.explanation: A green light tells you that you can go through the intersection. However, you must first yield the right-of-way to traffic and pedestrians who are still in the intersection.

questions.question: While backing, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your lights.
questions.answerC: Open your door to see if it is safe to proceed.
questions.answerD: Turn your head and look through the rear window.
questions.explanation: When intending to back up, always check behind your vehicle before getting in. Children and small objects are difficult to see from the driver’s seat. While backing, turn your head so you can see through the rear window. Do not depend only on your mirrors or sensors.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers that:
questions.answerA: The right lane is ending and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: The road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: There are upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that the number of lanes is reduced ahead and that traffic should merge left.

questions.question: Certain highway signs require drivers to obey an indicated instruction. Such signs are known as:
questions.answerB: Warning signs.
questions.answerC: Information signs.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs require drivers to obey an indicated instruction. Failure to comply is subject to penalty.

questions.question: As the percentage of alcohol (BAC) in your blood increases, you become:
questions.answerB: More sober.
questions.answerC: More coordinated.
questions.explanation: Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is a measure of the percentage of alcohol in a person's blood. The higher the BAC, the more impaired a person is.

questions.question: What does an orange-colored sign indicate?
questions.answerA: The start of a no passing zone.
questions.answerB: A railroad crossing is ahead.
questions.answerC: A school zone is ahead.
questions.explanation: Construction, maintenance, and emergency operations signs are generally orange with black symbols.

questions.question: If you are following a school bus or tank truck, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop at all railroad crossings.
questions.explanation: School buses and tank trucks carrying flammable liquids must stop at all railroad crossings before proceeding, regardless of the presence of a train. Be prepared to stop at all railroad tracks if following one of these vehicles.

questions.question: Double solid yellow lines painted down the middle of the road mean:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerD: Passing is permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines in the center of the road mean that passing is not allowed from either direction. You may not cross the lines unless you are making a left turn or passing pedestrians, bicyclists, and riders of scooters or skateboards when the opposite lane is clear and you can pass safely.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Left turn signal.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that parking is not permitted.

questions.question: In inclement weather, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive in a low gear.
questions.answerC: Steer and brake smoothly.
questions.explanation: When driving during unfavorable weather conditions, avoid slamming on the brakes and making sharp, quick turns. These behaviors will make controlling your vehicle in inclement weather even more difficult.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Begin signaling as you move into the next lane.
questions.answerC: Signal at least 500 feet before your lane change when driving on residential streets.
questions.explanation: Other cars and motorcycles are often hidden in a vehicle’s blind spot, so be sure to glance over your shoulder before you begin a lane change. Begin signaling 100 feet before changing lanes or turning in a residential area. Signal five seconds in advance when changing lanes on a freeway.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Railroad crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Intersection ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign means that you are approaching an upcoming intersection. Watch carefully for cross traffic.

questions.question: Consuming which of the following substances may impair your ability to drive safely and may result in an arrest for driving under the influence of intoxicants (DUII)?
questions.answerB: Controlled substances, such as illegal drugs or prescription medicines
questions.answerC: Inhalants, such as glue or paint
questions.explanation: A wide variety of intoxicants can impair your ability to drive. These include all types of alcoholic beverages, illegal drugs, inhalants, and many legal medications (both prescription and over-the-counter).

questions.question: Fatigue increases the risk of:
questions.answerB: Being late for an appointment.
questions.answerC: Falling asleep behind the wheel and crashing.
questions.explanation: Fatigue causes errors related to speed and distance, increases your risk of being in a crash, and causes you to take more time to make decisions. When you are fatigued, you could fall asleep behind the wheel and crash, injuring or killing yourself or others.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery when it first starts to rain.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Oil, rubber, dirt, and water combine to make roads especially slippery when it first starts to rain. Drivers should decrease their speeds on slippery roads.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Maintain your speed and stay in your lane until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerB: Move into the right lane and drive slowly until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the curb or edge of the road and stop until the vehicle has passed.
questions.explanation: If you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights, pull over to the right edge of the road and stop. Position yourself parallel to the curb. On one-way streets, drive toward the road edge nearest you.

questions.question: When you see other drivers around you acting or reacting in anger:
questions.answerB: Don't react with hand gestures.
questions.answerC: Distance yourself from the situation.
questions.explanation: When other drivers are behaving angrily, you should take action to physically and mentally distance yourself from the situation. Avoid making eye contact with them, or making body movements or gestures that could provoke them. Slow down, move over, or do whatever you safely can to put yourself out of danger.

questions.question: To prevent yourself from becoming an aggressive driver:
questions.answerB: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Tailgate the driver in front of you.
questions.explanation: To prevent yourself from becoming an aggressive driver, concentrate on driving and don't take the actions of other drivers personally. Be realistic about your travel time, drive within posted speed limits, and be forgiving of other drivers using the roadway.

questions.question: While driving at night, a vehicle coming toward you has its high beams on, making it hard for you to see the road ahead. You should:
questions.answerA: Look ahead toward the left edge of your lane.
questions.answerB: Look ahead toward the right edge of your lane.
questions.answerC: Look straight ahead in your lane.
questions.explanation: If an oncoming driver fails to dim their high beams, you should avoid looking directly at the headlights. Instead, look toward the right edge of your lane and watch the oncoming vehicle out of the corner of your eye.

questions.question: If a High Intensity Activated Crosswalk signal is solid red, it means:
questions.answerB: Drivers should slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerC: Drivers should come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: HAWK signals are used at pedestrian crossings. If the signal light turns to a solid red, drivers must come to a complete stop.

questions.question: As a pedestrian, you should:
questions.answerA: Always insist on the right-of-way over a vehicle when using a crosswalk.
questions.answerB: Never enter a street or crosswalk when vehicles are approaching.
questions.answerC: Enter a crosswalk at any time because it is the vehicle driver’s responsibility to stop.
questions.answerD: Use crosswalks only if they are convenient.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians should not enter a street or crosswalk when vehicles are approaching. Though pedestrians have the right-of-way in crosswalks, a vehicle approaching from a close distance may not have the time to stop before entering the crosswalk.

questions.question: When driving on a slippery surface, such as snow or ice:
questions.answerA: Shift to a low gear before going down steep hills.
questions.answerB: Maintain traction by following other vehicles closely.
questions.answerC: Pump your brakes to keep them from freezing.
questions.explanation: To prevent skidding on slippery surfaces, you should shift to a low gear before going down a steep hill. You should also follow farther behind the vehicle in front of you than you normally would. Quick stops should be avoided. Unless you have antilock brakes, pump the brakes to slow or stop.

questions.question: This yellow warning sign means:
questions.answerA: You are approaching a school or school crosswalk.
questions.answerB: Slow down, drive with caution, and watch for children.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: This sign is placed on roads near schools to warn drivers to slow down, drive with caution, and watch for children.

questions.question: What is the only way to reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerB: Exercise.
questions.answerC: Allow your body time to get rid of the alcohol.
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is to not drink alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: To reduce the effects of headlight glare at night, you should look:
questions.answerB: Over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: At the center of the road
questions.answerD: To the right edge of the road.
questions.explanation: If oncoming drivers do not dim their headlights for you, keep your eyes on the right side of the road ahead. Do not look directly at the oncoming headlights because the glare may blind you for several seconds.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Drive only in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerC: Curve ahead.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. Where this sign is present, drivers must drive in the direction indicated by the arrow.

questions.question: Only ____ can reduce blood alcohol content (BAC) and alcohol's effects on the body.
questions.answerB: Eating foods high in fat
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: Only the passage of time can remove alcohol and its impairing effects from the body.

questions.question: To change lanes you should:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors and signal, then change lanes.
questions.answerB: Signal, check your mirrors, check your blind spot in the direction you plan to move, then change lanes.
questions.answerC: Signal, check your mirrors, and change lanes.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should activate your turn signal in the appropriate direction and check your rearview and side mirrors. Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move in order to check your blind spot and check the far lane to be sure no one else is trying to enter the same lane as you. Change lanes when you are sure it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection with a flashing yellow light. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and wait for the light to change.
questions.answerB: Make a U-turn because the intersection is closed.
questions.answerC: Drive carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerD: Prepare to stop; the light is about to turn red.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light means that you should proceed through the intersection slowly and with caution. Scan your eyes across traffic in both directions.

questions.question: Which of the following is a dangerous habit when driving in work zones?
questions.answerB: Failing to carefully watch for workers and moving equipment
questions.answerC: Both of the above
questions.explanation: When driving in a work zone, adjust your speed for the traffic conditions and don't follow other vehicles too closely. Be attentive to workers and machines in the work zone.

questions.question: When driving to an unfamiliar area, you:
questions.answerA: Should depend on road signs to find your way.
questions.answerB: Should plan your trip in advance.
questions.answerC: Only have to know generally where your destination is.
questions.answerD: Should always choose the most direct route.
questions.explanation: When driving to an unfamiliar area, plan your trip in advance. Don’t start with only a hazy idea of where you are going. If your destination is in an unfamiliar area, check the location on a map before you start to drive.

questions.question: Emotions do not affect the way we drive.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Strong emotions, such as fear and anger, can affect the way we perceive and process information. Therefore, emotions often affect the way we drive.

questions.question: How can you lower the risk of hydroplaning?
questions.answerA: Do not speed when the roads are wet.
questions.answerB: Use tires with proper air pressure.
questions.answerC: Replace tires with bad tread.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning happens when a vehicle glides on top of a thin layer of water between its tires and the road. Tires with low air pressure or bad tread can increase the risk of hydroplaning. Speeding also increases the risk.

questions.question: Water on the road can cause a vehicle to hydroplane. Your car may hydroplane at speeds as low as:
questions.answerB: 35 miles per hour.
questions.answerC: 40 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when there is standing water on a roadway. At speeds up to 35 mph, most tires will channel water away from the tire. As your speed increases past 35 mph, tires cannot channel the water as well and your tires may start to lose contact with the road and ride over the water like a set of water skis.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beam headlights may cause the light to reflect off of the fog and into your eyes.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Double curve.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead winds with a series of turns or curves.

questions.question: Which of the following road surfaces freezes first?
questions.answerB: An intersection
questions.answerC: A bridge
questions.explanation: Pavement on bridges and overpasses can become icy even when other surrounding pavement is dry. Bridges often freeze before, and thaw out after, the rest of a road.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident. You should:
questions.answerB: Help the injured.
questions.answerC: Call the police.
questions.explanation: If involved in an accident, you should stop your vehicle immediately. If possible, move the vehicle out of the way of traffic. Call the nearest police agency and ask for an ambulance, if necessary. Do not move the injured unnecessarily, but attempt to stop severe bleeding with direct pressure. Wait for emergency vehicles to arrive.

questions.question: You may not cross a single broken white or yellow line:
questions.answerA: When doing so would interfere with traffic.
questions.answerB: When turning left into a driveway.
questions.answerC: When the car in front of you is disabled.
questions.answerD: When passing to the right on a one-way street.
questions.explanation: You may cross a single broken line to pass or change lanes as long as you can do so safely and without interfering with traffic.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop, if necessary.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.answerD: Drive with caution and be ready to stop.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided sign always means "stop." You must come to a complete stop and wait for any vehicles or pedestrians to clear the way before proceeding.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Drive with caution and be ready to slow down.
questions.answerB: Do not drive in this lane.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop and yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Slow down, be prepared to stop, and, if necessary, yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This type of triangular sign means drivers must yield. You must slow down as you come to an intersection marked with this sign and be prepared to stop. Let any other vehicles, bicyclists, or pedestrians pass safely before you proceed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins.
questions.answerC: Lane ends.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane ends ahead. A merging maneuver will be required for drivers in that lane.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Flagger ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way left turn.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign means that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Turn right at the intersection.
questions.answerC: Parking area ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the presence of a crossroad ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: You must stop for flaggers.
questions.answerC: The road ahead is closed to traffic.
questions.answerD: The highway ahead is undergoing maintenance.
questions.explanation: Construction and maintenance signs are orange-colored and are used to notify drivers of unusual or potentially dangerous conditions in or near work areas. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a construction zone and that they should prepare to lower their speed and drive with extraordinary caution.

questions.question: Nighttime is the safest time for cyclists to ride their bikes.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: A bicycle is difficult to see in the dark, even when the cyclist is wearing a proper headlight and reflector. Both motorists and bicyclists should be especially alert when driving at night in order to prevent dangerous collisions.

questions.question: You reach an intersection with stop signs on all four corners at the same time as the driver on your left. Who has the right-of-way?
questions.answerA: The driver on your left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: You have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Whoever is signaling to make a turn has the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: If two vehicles arrive at the same time to an intersection that has stop signs on all corners, the vehicle to the right has the right-of-way.

questions.question: Driving is a privilege, not a right.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Driving a motor vehicle is a privilege and not a right. Holding a license to drive carries a serious responsibility to keep yourself and others safe.

questions.question: Only ____ can lower blood alcohol concentration (BAC) and reduce alcohol's effects on a body.
questions.answerB: Eating foods high in fat
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: The only way to sober up after drinking alcohol is to allow time for your body to eliminate the alcohol in your system. Nothing you can do, including eating and drinking, can accelerate this process.

questions.question: You want to back out of your driveway. You see children playing nearby. Before you start to move your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Rev your engine to warn the children that you are moving.
questions.answerB: Sound your horn so the children will hear you.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the car to be sure the way is clear.
questions.answerD: Tell the children to stay away from the driveway.
questions.explanation: When you back up a vehicle, look through your back window for pedestrians and other obstacles. Do not rely only on your mirrors, especially when children are near. Before you back into or out of a driveway, get out of the vehicle and check behind your vehicle.

questions.question: If a road is slippery, maintain a following distance that is:
questions.answerB: Farther from the car ahead than normal.
questions.answerC: Closer to the car ahead than normal.
questions.explanation: You need a longer distance to stop your vehicle on a slippery road than you do on a dry road. Maintain an increased following distance when driving on slippery roads.

questions.question: Vehicles stopped behind a school bus with its red lights flashing must remain stopped until:
questions.answerA: All students are off the bus.
questions.answerB: The stop arm is retracted.
questions.answerC: The stop arm is retracted and the bus resumes motion.
questions.explanation: When a school bus is flashing its red lights and has its stop arm extended, motorists must come to a full stop until the lights are turned off, the stop arm is withdrawn, and the bus begins moving again.

questions.question: You may drive around the gates at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: When the lights have stopped flashing.
questions.answerD: When other drivers drive around the gates.
questions.explanation: You are required to stop at all railroad crossings when signals warn of an approaching train. These signals may include flashing red lights, a lowered crossing gate, a flagger signaling, or a train’s audible signal of warning. Do not attempt to go around a lowered gate.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of two-way traffic ahead.

questions.question: You are driving on the freeway behind a large truck. You should drive:
questions.answerA: Closer behind the truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle.
questions.answerB: Farther behind the truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: To the right side of the truck and wait to pass.
questions.explanation: It is necessary to follow farther behind a large truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle because trucks have larger blind spots.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits drivers from making a U-turn. You cannot turn around to go in the opposite direction at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: Make room for cars that are entering the freeway by:
questions.answerB: Merging into a different lane.
questions.answerC: Maintaining your speed and position.
questions.explanation: Make room for vehicles that are entering a freeway. If possible, merge into the next lane to create a gap for the incoming vehicles. If you cannot merge, adjust your speed to allow for the vehicles to enter traffic as smoothly and safely as possible.

questions.question: Sudden wind gusts on highways:
questions.answerA: Generally affect only the movement of large vehicles.
questions.answerB: Only cause visibility problems.
questions.answerC: Can cause problems for all vehicles.
questions.explanation: While it can create special problems for large vehicles, strong wind can cause problems for all drivers. Wind can lower visibility by blowing dirt and dust into the roadway, but it can sometimes also physically move a vehicle.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Low ground railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. You should not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height shown on the sign (in this case, 13 feet 6 inches).

questions.question: When driving at night, you should:
questions.answerB: Look directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: Increase your following distance when it is difficult to see due to darkness. Use headlights to increase visibility, following the rules for proper use of high beams and low beams. Avoid looking directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle to avoid being blinded by the glare.

questions.question: In the winter, if a road surface seems dry, it's definitely dry.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Roads that seem dry may actually be slippery and dangerous, especially during the winter. Be prepared to encounter black ice on the roadway, especially when approaching intersections, off-ramps, bridges, or shady areas.

questions.question: A person's ability to drive can be impaired by:
questions.answerB: Any medication.
questions.answerC: A lack of sleep.
questions.explanation: The ability to drive safely is dependent on the driver being in good physical condition. Driving can be impaired by alcohol, legal and illegal drugs, and being drowsy.

questions.question: The faster the speed of your vehicle, the longer it takes to stop when you must react to other drivers' unexpected movements.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: The faster you are driving, the longer it will take for you to stop to react to other drivers' unexpected moves.

questions.question: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit in a residential area is:
questions.answerB: 35 mph.
questions.answerC: 25 mph.
questions.explanation: When driving in a residential area, the maximum speed limit is 25 miles per hour. If a different speed limit is posted, follow the posted speed limit.

questions.question: After you have passed a vehicle moving in the same direction, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
questions.answerB: When you can no longer see the passed vehicle over your right shoulder.
questions.answerC: When you can see the entire front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When passing, you should not return to your original lane until you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. Always check your blind spots before moving back into your original lane.

questions.question: When may you proceed through an intersection that has a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk?
questions.answerA: After slowing down to verify that there is no cross traffic
questions.answerB: After coming to a complete stop and verifying that it is safe to proceed
questions.answerC: After you have stopped at least 20 feet prior to the intersection
questions.answerD: After slowing down to a speed of 10 mph
questions.explanation: Stop before the stop line or crosswalk at any intersection that is controlled by a stop sign. If there is a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When may you turn off your mechanical turn signal?
questions.answerB: In the middle of a turn
questions.answerC: After completing your turn
questions.explanation: Activate your turn signal before beginning a turn to alert surrounding drivers to your intentions. Complete the turn before turning off your signal.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you can check your blind spots by:
questions.answerB: Using the outside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Using both inside and outside rearview mirrors.
questions.answerD: Turning your head and looking over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: You should turn your head to check your blind spots before every lane change.

questions.question: You should honk your horn when you:
questions.answerB: Are passing a bicyclist.
questions.answerC: See a child who is about to run into the street.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used as a warning in situations where you think another driver or a pedestrian does not see you. For example, if a child begins to run into the street in front of your vehicle, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: When encountering an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Avoid eye contact, slow down, and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Cut them off to slow them down.
questions.answerC: Retaliate by tailgating them.
questions.answerD: Make sure they know you disapprove of their behavior.
questions.explanation: If another driver is threatening you or intentionally driving dangerously around you, remain calm and try to put as much distance between the two of you as possible. Slow down and let them pass. Do not make eye contact and do not make obscene gestures.

questions.question: If you approach a traffic light with a red signal and a police officer directs you to go through the intersection without stopping, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the light turns green.
questions.answerB: Go through the intersection without stopping.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop before proceeding.
questions.explanation: Instructions given by police officers directing traffic always override posted traffic signals and signs. Follow the officer's instructions.

questions.question: What kinds of drugs can affect your driving ability?
questions.answerB: Marijuana
questions.answerC: Cold remedies
questions.explanation: Many kinds of drugs can impair your ability to drive. This includes illegal drugs and legal prescription or over-the-counter medications. It can be a criminal offense to drive while impaired by any drug.

questions.question: When a car with bright headlights drives toward you at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the other driver passes.
questions.answerB: Look below their headlights.
questions.answerC: Glance toward the right edge of your lane.
questions.explanation: To avoid being blinded when driving at night, do not look directly at the headlights of oncoming cars. Instead, look toward the right edge of the road until the oncoming driver has passed.

questions.question: When approaching a roundabout, you should always:
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: When approaching a roundabout, you should slow down. A roundabout is designed to be driven at a low speed.

questions.question: In rainy weather, you should be most careful when turning or stopping:
questions.answerA: After it has been raining all day.
questions.answerB: One half hour after it stops raining.
questions.answerC: During the first half hour of rain.
questions.explanation: You should be extra careful when turning and stopping during the first half hour of rain. At this point, the oil from cars has not yet washed off the pavement and could be forming a slippery mixture with the rain.

questions.question: You may not complete a turnabout:
questions.answerA: If it requires you to cross a double yellow line.
questions.answerB: Where it may interfere with surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Where hills and curves are nearby.
questions.explanation: If you intend to make a turnabout, you must first be sure that it is permitted in the area. Observe your surroundings and check for hills and curves, signs prohibiting turnabouts, double yellow lines, traffic, and visibility.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about driving speed is true?
questions.answerA: As your speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases.
questions.answerB: As your speed increases, so should your following distance.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: As driving speeds increase, the chance of a fatality in the case of a collision increases. If you are going faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. The speed you drive affects your stopping distance, so you should increase your following distance as you increase your speed.

questions.question: When driving in fog, it is best to drive with:
questions.answerB: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: Use low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow. High beams may reflect off of the weather and make visibility even poorer.

questions.question: You must yield for emergency vehicles:
questions.answerB: When you see a flashing red or blue light or hear a siren.
questions.answerC: Only when other vehicles yield.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren or flashing lights.

questions.question: A yellow light that flashes on and off means:
questions.answerA: Stop and look for other vehicles, then go if there is no traffic.
questions.answerB: Stop and wait for a green light.
questions.answerC: Speed up to clear the intersection quickly.
questions.answerD: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light means drivers should slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: Decrease your speed as you approach an intersection with a yield sign. Prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in the intersection or crossroad. You must come to a full stop at a yield sign if traffic conditions require it.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop only if other cars are approaching.
questions.answerC: Bicycle store.
questions.explanation: This sign (with the arrow below) indicates the location of a bicycle crossing/path. Drive with caution around this sign because bicycles likely regularly cross or ride beside traffic in the area.

questions.question: If you are driving in another driver's blind spot, you should:
questions.answerA: Move forward or drop back so the other driver can see you.
questions.answerB: Keep a steady pace.
questions.answerC: Stay in the driver's blind spot.
questions.answerD: Honk to let them know you are there.
questions.explanation: Do not drive in someone else’s blind spot. Move forward or drop back so that the other driver can see you.

questions.question: This sign means that:
questions.answerA: A community service group is picking up trash along the highway ahead.
questions.answerB: Workers are on or very close to the road in the work zone ahead.
questions.answerC: Children are at play ahead.
questions.answerD: There is a pedestrian crosswalk ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that workers may be on or very close to the roadway ahead, so you should take special care when traveling through the area.

questions.question: When you drive through a construction zone, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Pass the construction zone carefully and not “rubberneck."
questions.explanation: To avoid contributing to chronic traffic congestion, you should not "rubberneck." That is, you should not slow down to look at out-of-the-ordinary things.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers:
questions.answerA: That the right lane ends and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: That the road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: About upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane on a multilane roadway ends ahead. Traffic in the right lane must merge left.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal when changing lanes, pulling into or out of a parking space, or pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent accidents.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks are permitted on an upcoming narrow bridge.
questions.answerB: The bridge ahead is open to one-way traffic only.
