questions.answerC: The bridge ahead is wide enough for only one car at a time.
questions.answerD: The bridge ahead may be too narrow to meet or pass a truck.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that an upcoming bridge may be too narrow to meet or pass a truck and that they should be careful.

questions.question: Bicycles on the road:
questions.answerA: Must always yield the right-of-way to motor vehicles.
questions.answerB: Do not follow specific rules of the road.
questions.answerC: Are nothing to worry about.
questions.answerD: Are considered vehicles with the same rights and responsibilities as motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: Bicycles on the road are considered vehicles and have the same rights and responsibilities as motor vehicles. Drivers of motor vehicles should respect the rights of bicyclists.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady green arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn in the direction of the arrow after yielding to traffic and pedestrians already in the intersection.
questions.answerD: May drive straight through the intersection.
questions.explanation: A green arrow displayed on a traffic signal tells drivers that they may turn in the direction of the arrow. You must be in the proper lane for such a turn. Yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians already in the intersection.

questions.question: When approaching railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerA: Look, listen, slow down, and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerB: Speed up to cross the tracks before the gate is lowered.
questions.answerC: Try to drive around a lowered gate.
questions.answerD: Not pay attention to how many tracks there are to cross.
questions.explanation: When approaching railroad tracks, you should look, listen, slow down, and be prepared to stop for trains or other vehicles that may be using the rails.

questions.question: When passing another car, you have enough space to return to the driving lane:
questions.answerA: If the other driver signals for you to re-enter the lane.
questions.answerB: If you look over your shoulder and see the passed car behind you.
questions.answerC: If you can see both of the passed vehicle's headlights in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Before you return to the driving lane when completing a pass, be sure there is a safe gap between your vehicle and the passed vehicle. When you can see both headlights of the vehicle in your rearview mirror, it is safe to return to the driving lane.

questions.question: Never try to pass more than one vehicle at a time.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Never try to pass more than one vehicle at a time. Only pass another vehicle when it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: Increase your following distance when driving behind a large vehicle:
questions.answerA: To better see around the sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Because other drivers tend to pull behind large vehicles before trying to pass them.
questions.answerC: Because following too closely will get you caught in the vehicle's slipstream.
questions.explanation: Drivers of trucks, buses, vans, and any vehicles pulling campers or trailers may not be able to see you if you are driving directly behind them. Increase your following distance when driving behind one of these vehicles. Additionally, large vehicles can block your view of the road, so increase your following distance to look around the sides of the vehicle and see the road ahead.

questions.question: A driver should be extra alert to motorcyclists, bicyclists, and pedestrians because:
questions.answerA: They’re difficult to see in traffic.
questions.answerB: They obey different traffic laws than larger motor vehicles.
questions.answerC: They always have the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: In many collisions with motorcycles, bicycles, and pedestrians, drivers reported that they were looking but still did not see the smaller vehicle or pedestrian. These can be more difficult to spot in traffic than passenger vehicles because they are smaller, may move faster, and have less noticeable lighting. To prevent collisions with these smaller and less protected road users, drivers should always be alert to the presence of motorcycles, bikes, and pedestrians.

questions.question: Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian who is:
questions.answerB: In any crosswalk or intersection.
questions.answerC: Crossing any street.
questions.explanation: Drivers must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians who are crossing the street in any marked or unmarked crosswalk. In the interest of safety, drivers should yield the right-of-way to people crossing any street.

questions.question: You are on the freeway and traffic is merging into your lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Make room for the merging traffic, if possible.
questions.answerB: Assert your right-of-way by driving faster.
questions.answerC: Always maintain your position.
questions.explanation: When traffic permits, you should make room to allow vehicles to merge into your lane.

questions.question: A speed restriction sign:
questions.answerA: May be ignored in rainy, snowy, or icy conditions.
questions.answerB: Has a triangular shape.
questions.answerC: Is blue with black lettering.
questions.answerD: Shows a recommended speed for a curve or turn.
questions.explanation: Curve and turn warning signs often have attached advisory speed signs that show a recommended driving speed for drivers in the curves and turns. Although a driver may feel comfortable driving at a higher speed in fair weather, they should never do so under rainy, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This signs indicate that U-turns are prohibited in the location where it is posted.

questions.question: You may not complete a turnabout:
questions.answerA: If it requires you to cross a double yellow line.
questions.answerB: Where it may interfere with surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Where hills and curves are nearby.
questions.explanation: If you intend to make a turnabout, you must first be sure that it is permitted in the area. Observe your surroundings and check for hills and curves, signs prohibiting turnabouts, double yellow lines, traffic, and visibility.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, you should:
questions.answerA: Be prepared for a person or vehicle to unexpectedly enter your lane.
questions.answerB: Expect all other drivers and pedestrians to respect your right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Drive closely to the parked vehicles to allow more room for moving traffic.
questions.explanation: Keep a space between your vehicle and parked vehicles. A person may step out of a parked vehicle or out from between the parked vehicles without looking. A driver may begin moving their vehicle before realizing you are there.

questions.question: You may not park within ____ of a fire hydrant.
questions.answerB: 15 feet
questions.answerC: Eight feet
questions.explanation: You may not park within eight feet of a fire hydrant. Only park where you will not be disruptive to traffic and where other drivers can clearly see your vehicle from every direction.

questions.question: What should you do if your accelerator sticks while you are driving?
questions.answerA: Reach down and attempt to pull it up.
questions.answerB: Shift to park.
questions.answerC: Shift to neutral and apply steady pressure on the brake.
questions.explanation: If your accelerator sticks while you are driving, keep your eyes on the road. Quickly shift the vehicle into neutral and apply steady pressure on the brake pedal. Pull off the road when it is safe to do so and turn off the engine.

questions.question: Larger vehicles have:
questions.answerB: Smaller blind spots.
questions.answerC: No blind spots.
questions.answerD: The same blind spots as smaller vehicles.
questions.explanation: The larger the vehicle, the larger the blind spots. Large trucks and SUVs have spots close to their rears that cannot be seen in their side or rearview mirrors.

questions.question: A “No stopping” sign means that, unless directed to do so by a police officer, you may stop only:
questions.answerB: To avoid conflict with other traffic.
questions.answerC: To discharge passengers.
questions.explanation: A "No stopping" sign means you can only stop to obey a traffic signal, to obey a police officer, or to prevent a conflict with another vehicle.

questions.question: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Get out of their way.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.explanation: Drivers must respect and cooperate with all other road users and conform to specific rules in order to maintain order and to avoid crashes. When encountering an aggressive driver, it is safest to just get out of their way. Always avoid competing with other drivers.

questions.question: Drivers must be careful when passing large vehicles and should avoid driving beside large vehicles for long periods of time.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Because large vehicles have large blind spots on both sides, you should avoid driving beside a large vehicle for a long period of time. It is safest for you to either drop back or move forward when you find yourself directly next to a large vehicle.

questions.question: If you stop along the road at night:
questions.answerB: Use your parking lights only.
questions.answerC: Use your headlights only.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beams turned on.
questions.explanation: If you stop along the road at night, turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beam headlights turned on. Be sure that other road users will be able to clearly see your vehicle.

questions.question: You should not make sudden stops in front of large trucks and buses because:
questions.answerA: Small vehicle drivers cannot adequately see large trucks and buses in their rearview mirrors.
questions.answerB: Large trucks and buses, due to their size and weight, require longer distances to stop than smaller passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Large trucks and buses travel at a higher speeds than small vehicles.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles require longer distances to stop and accelerate than smaller vehicles do. Making a sudden stop in front of a large vehicle is dangerous because the other driver may not be able to stop in time to avoid a collision.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Upcoming intersection.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers of an upcoming intersection so they may prepare for potential traffic or prepare to turn.

questions.question: You notice a vehicle defect which may affect the safe operation of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Correct the defect as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Correct the defect when you can afford it.
questions.answerC: Drive the vehicle at slower speeds.
questions.explanation: Any defect that may affect the safe operation of a vehicle should be corrected as soon as possible. Defects should be corrected before the vehicle is driven.

questions.question: Certain highway signs contain information about hazardous conditions. Such signs are known as:
questions.answerB: Warning signs.
questions.answerC: Information signs.
questions.explanation: Warning signs advise drivers of potentially hazardous conditions. For your own safety, obey warning signs. Disregarding the information provided by a warning sign may result in an accident due to your negligence.

questions.question: If a vehicle using high beams comes toward you, you should look toward ____ of the road.
questions.answerB: The center
questions.answerC: The right side
questions.explanation: If a vehicle approaching you is using its high beams and fails to dim them, you should glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see well enough to stay on your course until the vehicle passes.

questions.question: You cannot pass safely on a two-way, two-lane street unless:
questions.answerA: You are able to clearly see the road ahead.
questions.answerB: You can return to your lane before meeting oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Your vehicle is capable of the speed necessary to pass.
questions.explanation: You cannot pass safely when driving on a two-way, two-lane street unless you can clearly see the road ahead, you can return to your lane before meeting oncoming traffic, and your vehicle is capable of the speed necessary to pass. Do not pass where it is illegal and unsafe to do so.

questions.question: You may cross double solid yellow lines:
questions.answerB: To turn into a driveway.
questions.answerC: To pass another car.
questions.explanation: Double solid lines indicate that you may not pass or change lanes. You cannot cross the lines unless it is to turn left to enter or exit a highway, to turn into or from a driveway, or to make a U-turn (where permitted).

questions.question: Continuous hard braking on ice and snow often:
questions.answerB: Locks the front wheels of a vehicle, causing a loss of steering.
questions.answerC: Keeps the brakes from freezing.
questions.explanation: Continuous hard braking on snow and ice can result in the locking of the front brake, causing a loss of steering. To avoid the need for excessive braking, make sure to maintain an appropriate speed for conditions.

questions.question: You may drive across a dashed white line:
questions.answerB: Only during daylight hours.
questions.answerC: When it is safe to change lanes.
questions.explanation: Traffic lanes moving in the same direction are separated by broken white lines. You may cross over dashed lines to pass, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When you see or hear an emergency vehicle coming, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop immediately and let the vehicle pass.
questions.answerB: Drive as far toward the right side of the road as is safe and stop.
questions.answerC: Proceed slowly and permit the vehicle to pass.
questions.answerD: Keep moving slowly, staying to the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: When driving on a two-lane roadway or undivided highway, you must yield to an emergency vehicle using its lights and/or siren, regardless of the direction from which it is approaching. Immediately drive as near as possible to the right side of the road and stop, taking care not to stop within an intersection.

questions.question: When riding in a vehicle, small children:
questions.answerA: May be safely held by a strong adult.
questions.answerB: Will be safe if they are standing on the floor in the back of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will not be hurt in an accident because they are small.
questions.answerD: Must never be allowed to ride while standing in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Special child seats are available for children who are too small to wear regular safety belts. No person is strong enough to safely hold onto a child of any size during an accident or sudden stop. Never allow a child to ride in a vehicle unless they are properly fastened into a seat.

questions.question: If you plan to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Not assume the other driver will make space for you to return to your lane.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver will let you pass if you use your turn signal.
questions.answerC: Assume the other driver will maintain a constant speed.
questions.explanation: Even when you signal, you should not assume that the space you want to occupy is free or that other drivers will give you the right-of-way.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Road construction/maintenance area.
questions.answerC: Traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign is displayed on slow-moving vehicles.

questions.question: Two solid white lines painted across a traffic lane show the boundaries of a crosswalk. As a driver, you should know that:
questions.answerA: Motor vehicles have the right-of-way over pedestrians in crosswalks.
questions.answerB: When pedestrians are in crosswalks, they should be given the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: No one has the right-of-way in a crosswalk.
questions.answerD: Pedestrians are responsible to stay out of the way of all traffic.
questions.explanation: Crosswalk lines show pedestrians where to safely cross a road or street. Crosswalks may be marked by horizontal lines, vertical lines, or a combination of the two. You must always stop for pedestrians who are in a crosswalk.

questions.question: If you can see that the roadway up ahead is covered by heavy smoke, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on your four-way flashers and continue.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed, move as far to the right as possible, and stop off the roadway.
questions.answerC: Turn on your high beam headlights and continue.
questions.explanation: If you notice that the road ahead is covered by heavy smoke, reduce your speed immediately, drive as far as possible to the right, and stop off the roadway. Only then should you determine if it is safe for you to continue. Remember that certain kinds of smoke can irritate your eyes and lungs or even kill you.

questions.question: It is important to be alert to motorcycles because:
questions.answerA: They are more difficult to see than cars.
questions.answerB: They rarely use their headlights.
questions.answerC: Motorcyclists are less skilled drivers than other motorists.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles are smaller and harder to see than cars. Because of their size, they are easily hidden in a car’s blind spot. It may be difficult to judge your distance to a motorcycle and difficult to tell how fast a motorcycle is moving, so always be alert and extra cautious when near a motorcyclist.

questions.question: The act of turning your head and checking your blind spot before changing lanes, driving away from a curb, or merging your vehicle into traffic is:
questions.answerB: A good driving habit.
questions.answerC: Unnecessary.
questions.answerD: Not necessary if you use the rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, it is important to check your blind spots. Do this by looking over your shoulder toward the next lane. Do not rely only on your mirrors.

questions.question: When approaching a person who is crossing the street while using a white cane or guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the person is well away from your path of travel.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn as you proceed past them.
questions.answerC: Carefully drive around them.
questions.explanation: When approaching a pedestrian who is using a white cane or guide dog while crossing the street, you must stop until the person is well away from your path of travel. Always yield the right-of-way to blind pedestrians.

questions.question: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or using a guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerB: Take the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Proceed normally.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or walking with a guide dog, you must slow down, yield the right-of-way, and then proceed with caution. Be prepared to stop your vehicle in order to prevent injury or danger to the pedestrian.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Railroad warning.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead.

questions.question: You should signal continuously while turning because it:
questions.answerA: Is illegal to turn off your signal before completing a turn.
questions.answerB: Lets other drivers know what your intentions are.
questions.answerC: Is always unsafe to turn off a signal before completing a turn.
questions.explanation: You should always signal when turning, changing lanes, slowing down, or stopping so that other drivers, motorcyclists, bicyclists, and pedestrians will know your intentions.

questions.question: You should signal to turn ____ before beginning the turn.
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.answerC: 20 feet
questions.explanation: If you wish to change lanes or make a turn, signal to inform other motorists of your intentions. Signals should be activated at least 100 feet before you begin the turn. Continue signaling until you have completed the turn or lane change.

questions.question: If bad weather makes it difficult for you to see clearly, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to get off the road quickly.
questions.answerB: Drive in the lane closest to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: When it is difficult to see due to darkness or poor weather, increase your following distance. This will give you more time to react to hazards that you may not see in advance.

questions.question: You are driving on a city street and see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights behind you. What should you do?
questions.answerA: Drive to the right edge of the road and slow down.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right edge of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane, slow down, and let it pass.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren and lights. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle has passed. If you are within an intersection, drive through the intersection first and then stop.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly is not an unsafe practice.
questions.answerB: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerC: The speed at which you drive a vehicle does not affect safety.
questions.explanation: Driving too slowly can be dangerous because it may cause drivers behind you to become frustrated and make dangerous moves to pass you. It is safest to drive with the flow of traffic, within the legal speed limit.

questions.question: If you miss your exit on an interstate expressway:
questions.answerB: Get off at the next exit and come back to the exit you missed.
questions.answerC: Roll down your window and ask the driver next to you for help.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up or try to turn around on the highway. Go to the next exit and safely turn around.

questions.question: Work zone signs mean:
questions.answerB: You must immediately stop and back up.
questions.answerC: Less than ideal conditions are present for driving.
questions.answerD: You should drive faster to get out of the work zone.
questions.explanation: Work zone signs are orange and indicate that some type of work is being performed on or alongside the roadway. Be extremely careful when you see these signs.

questions.question: What does a single dashed yellow line separating traffic mean?
questions.answerA: Drivers may pass if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerB: Both lanes travel in the same direction.
questions.answerC: Drivers may not pass.
questions.answerD: Drivers may pass, even if it could be dangerous.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic moving in opposite directions. A single dashed yellow line in the center of a road indicates that vehicles traveling in both directions are permitted to pass. Drivers may only begin a pass if they will not interfere with any oncoming traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Do not pass trucks.
questions.answerC: Truck parking area ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the presence of a hill ahead.

questions.question: Do not pass:
questions.answerB: When school bus lights are flashing.
questions.answerC: When approaching an intersection.
questions.explanation: You should never pass if there is an oncoming vehicle in the passing lane, if your view is blocked by a curve or hill, at an intersection, before or on a railroad crossing or bridge, or in any other no passing zone. Unless you are on the opposite side of a multilane roadway with a median or shared center turn lane, you may not pass a stopped school bus that has its flashing red lights activated.

questions.question: You are driving on a one-way street. You may only turn left onto another one-way street if:
questions.answerA: You increase your speed before the turn.
questions.answerB: Traffic on the street moves to the right.
questions.answerC: Traffic on the street moves to the left.
questions.explanation: You may turn left onto a one-way street that moves to the left if there is no sign prohibiting the turn. You may not turn left onto a one-way street where traffic moves to the right.

questions.question: At dusk or on overcast days, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive using your parking lights.
questions.answerC: Not turn on any vehicle lights.
questions.explanation: At dusk or on overcast days, you must turn on your headlights. Dim your lights to their low beam setting when within 1,000 feet of an approaching vehicle and when within 500 feet of a vehicle that you are following. When driving in poor weather, always use your low beams.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: School zone.
questions.explanation: A round yellow sign indicates that there is a railroad crossing ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Right turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Stop before turning right.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. Right turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: Alcohol is the single greatest common factor in fatal motor vehicle crashes.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Alcohol is the number one killer on American roadways. Alcohol affects a person’s vision and slows their reaction time, so it takes longer to act in an emergency. Alcohol affects a person’s driving even if they are below the level of illegal intoxication.

questions.question: To be safe when crossing a railroad, you should:
questions.answerA: Look both ways, but only when the red light is flashing.
questions.answerB: Listen, look both ways, and then proceed if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Cross especially quickly when a train is approaching.
questions.answerD: Quickly pass under any lowering gates.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings are always dangerous. Drivers should look and listen for an approaching train coming from either direction before proceeding across the tracks. Watch for signals indicating an approaching train and never proceed until you are certain it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When turning left, drivers must yield the right-of-way to:
questions.answerA: Other drivers who are already in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians who are already in the intersection.
questions.explanation: When turning left, drivers must yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic. Drivers must also always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians, bicyclists, and other drivers who are already in the intersection.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection and have a green light. Pedestrians are crossing against the red. You should:
questions.answerB: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Stop to let the pedestrians cross safely.
questions.answerD: Drive close to the pedestrians and frighten them so they’ll think twice before crossing against a red light.
questions.explanation: Yield to pedestrians and cars that may be caught in an intersection when you have a green light. Be careful around pedestrians under every circumstance.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Railroad crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Construction ahead.
questions.explanation: A round sign always indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing.

questions.question: If you need to stop quickly and your vehicle is not equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerB: Firmly pump your brakes.
questions.answerC: Lightly tap the brakes.
questions.explanation: Pumping the brakes is generally the best way to stop a car in an emergency. The car will stop quickly and you will also be able to continue steering.

questions.question: Having a driver license is a:
questions.answerB: Privilege.
questions.answerC: Right.
questions.explanation: It is important to remember that driving is a privilege and that all drivers play a role in ensuring that everyone remains safe on the roadways. If you prove to be abusive of that privilege, the privilege may be revoked.

questions.question: If a traffic light shows both a red light and a green arrow, a driver may not turn in the direction of the arrow until the red light has changed.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: After yielding the right-of-way to traffic within an intersection or crosswalk, a driver may go in the direction a green arrow is pointing, regardless of other lights present.

questions.question: You are driving when it begins to rain. You should:
questions.answerB: Drive at the maximum posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.answerD: Drive closely behind the vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: When heavy rain reduces visibility, reduce your speed. Turn on your headlights so other drivers can see your vehicle. If the rain is so heavy that you are unable to see clearly, drive onto the shoulder and stop until the rain lets up.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is an intersection with a side road ahead.

questions.question: To turn left from multilane, one-way streets and highways, you should start from:
questions.answerB: The right lane.
questions.answerC: The left lane.
questions.explanation: To turn left from multilane streets and highways, start from the left lane.

questions.question: Is it legal cross a double solid yellow centerline to pass?
questions.answerB: No.
questions.answerC: If there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: If the vehicle ahead of you is driving under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: Two solid yellow lines down the center of a two-way road mean that neither lane of traffic may cross the lines, unless they are turning off of the roadway. A driver can cross double yellow lines when turning into or out of a driveway or entrance to a business. No passing is allowed over a solid yellow line.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway starts.
questions.answerC: Divided highway ends.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the divided highway ends ahead. Prepare to change lanes or shift lane position.

questions.question: A distraction when driving is:
questions.answerA: Anything that causes evasive action while driving.
questions.answerB: Anything that takes your attention away from driving.
questions.answerC: Anything that causes you to pay more attention to driving.
questions.explanation: A distraction when driving is anything that takes your attention away from driving. Driver distractions may occur anytime and anywhere. Distracted driving can cause collisions, resulting in property damage, injury, and death.

questions.question: Alcohol in any concentration is:
questions.answerB: A depressant.
questions.answerC: Neither of the above.
questions.explanation: Alcohol, in any concentration, is a depressant. It slows all nerve impulses and bodily functions, resulting in a lessening of inhibitions and negatively affecting a consumer's ability to concentrate and stay alert.

questions.question: When you drive through an area where children are playing, you should expect them:
questions.answerA: To know when it is safe to cross the street.
questions.answerB: To stop at the curb before crossing the street.
questions.answerC: To run out in front of you without looking.
questions.answerD: Not to cross the street unless they are with an adult.
questions.explanation: You should always reduce your speed and use extra caution when children are in the vicinity. They may fail to understand the danger and may run out in front of you without looking.

questions.question: A leaky exhaust system in your vehicle is dangerous because it can cause:
questions.answerB: Pollution.
questions.answerC: Carbon monoxide poisoning.
questions.explanation: The exhaust system carries exhaust gas out of the vehicle and prevents fumes from entering into the passenger compartment. To prevent carbon monoxide poisoning, keep your exhaust system free of leaks. Replace all defective parts immediately.

questions.question: When you need to change lanes, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Signal your intentions ahead of the lane change.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Make sure the lane is clear before entering.
questions.explanation: Always signal for an appropriate amount of time before making a lane change or exiting a freeway. Before you make any move to the right or left, quickly turn your head and look over your shoulder to see if your blind spot is clear.

questions.question: When should you yield your legal right-of-way?
questions.answerB: Whenever it helps prevent collisions.
questions.answerC: Never. It confuses other drivers.
questions.explanation: Never assume other drivers will give you the right-of-way. Yield your right-of-way whenever it helps prevent collisions.

questions.question: The most effective safety restraints in a traffic crash are:
questions.answerA: Only a lap and shoulder belt.
questions.answerB: Only an airbag.
questions.answerC: Both a lap/shoulder belt and an airbag.
questions.explanation: Safety belts can double your chance of surviving a crash and more than double your chance of avoiding serious injury. Airbags, when used properly with safety belts, provide additional protection in a front-end crash. You should wear both shoulder and lap belts.

questions.question: Under normal weather and traffic conditions, keep a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.explanation: The more distance between your vehicle and others, the more time you have to react to the movements of surrounding vehicles. Keep a minimum following distance of three seconds under normal weather and traffic conditions. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: If you are driving and you see animals standing near the roadway:
questions.answerA: Speed up to scare them away.
questions.answerB: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Quickly swerve into the next lane.
questions.explanation: Slow down and proceed with caution if you see animals that are standing near the roadway. They may unexpectedly bolt or change direction at the last moment. Some animals travel in packs, so there may be more animals just out of sight that are also near the road.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for people crossing your path.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Work zone ahead.
questions.explanation: This orange warning sign tells drivers that an area of roadwork is upcoming. When traveling through a work zone, stay alert for temporary traffic control devices.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Trucks are entering the highway.
questions.answerC: Upcoming hill.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that drivers are approaching a steep hill and should prepare to adjust their speeds to continue to drive safely.

questions.question: You may honk your horn when you:
questions.answerB: Are passing another car.
questions.answerC: Have lost control of your car.
questions.explanation: One situation where it is appropriate to use your horn is if you lose control of your vehicle. In this case, sound your horn to alert other drivers.

questions.question: It is more dangerous to drive at night than during the day because:
questions.answerA: You cannot see as far ahead at night.
questions.answerB: The road is always more slippery at night.
questions.answerC: Your reaction time is slower at night.
questions.explanation: With decreased visibility and the glare of oncoming headlights, you cannot see as far ahead at night as you can during the day. Always use headlights and exercise caution when driving in the dark.

questions.question: To avoid glare from the headlights of an approaching car:
questions.answerA: Look briefly toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerB: Stay focused on the centerline on the road.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams.
questions.explanation: You should avoid looking toward the bright lights of an oncoming vehicle by glancing toward the right side of the road. After looking briefly toward the side of the road, continue looking ahead to check on the position of the other vehicle.

questions.question: Extra space in front of a large truck is needed for:
questions.answerA: Other drivers to merge onto the freeway.
questions.answerB: The truck driver to stop the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Other drivers when they want to slow down.
questions.explanation: Because they are larger, trucks take longer to stop than cars traveling at the same speed. Other drivers should not pull in front of a truck and then slow down or stop.

questions.question: You may text while driving:
questions.answerA: If you can text without looking at your phone.
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: If you are using a voice-to-text feature.
questions.answerD: If you only look away from the road for a moment.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving in Rhode Island is prohibited. Using a cellular telephone while driving is a major distraction to the operator of a motor vehicle.

questions.question: If you approach a stopped school bus that has its lights flashing and signal arm extended, you should:
questions.answerB: Proceed at 15 mph if no children are present.
questions.answerC: Proceed at normal speed, but watch for children.
questions.explanation: If you approach a stopped school bus that has its lights flashing and arm extended, you must come to a full stop and remain stopped until the signal arm is pulled back and the bus resumes motion. This law applies whether you are traveling in the same direction as the bus or if you are approaching from the opposite side of the street.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about drugs and driving?
questions.answerA: Any prescription drug is safe to use if you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerB: Even over-the-counter drugs can impair your driving.
questions.answerC: Only illegal drugs can impair your driving.
questions.explanation: Legal prescription and over-the-counter drugs can impair your ability to drive, including drugs taken for colds, hay fever, allergies, or to calm nerves or muscles. It is illegal to drive while under the influence of any drug that impairs your ability to drive safely; this law does not differentiate between illegal, prescription, or over-the-counter drugs.

questions.question: A fully loaded tractor-trailer traveling at 55 mph could take up to ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: 125 feet
questions.answerC: 400 feet
questions.explanation: Tractor-trailers take longer distances to stop than smaller cars traveling at the same speed. A fully loaded tractor-trailer may take almost 400 feet to come to a complete stop when driving at 55 mph.

questions.question: If you are turning onto a street with more than one lane traveling in your direction, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerB: Turn into the lane marked with an arrow.
questions.answerC: Turn into the middle lane.
questions.explanation: When turning onto a street with more than one lane moving in the direction that you are traveling, turn into the lane that is closest to your previous lane. Do not change lanes when turning.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Reduction in lanes.
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white sign indicates that you must yield the right-of-way.

questions.question: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Stop and proceed only when the intersection is clear.
questions.explanation: When encountering a flashing yellow light at an intersection, you should slow down and proceed with caution. You do not need to come to a complete stop when approaching a flashing yellow light.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Fire station.
questions.answerC: T intersection.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming traffic signal. They should be prepared to respond to a yellow light, red light, and/or cross traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Crossroad ahead.
questions.answerC: Keep right.
questions.explanation: Traffic signs with three sides of equal length warn drivers to slow down when approaching an intersection and to be prepared to come to a complete stop to yield to other drivers or pedestrians. Drivers may proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Your brake lights tell other drivers that you:
questions.answerB: Have your emergency brake on.
questions.answerC: Are changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's brake lights indicate to other drivers that you are slowing down or stopping. Your brake lights should always be in working order when you are driving on any roadway.

questions.question: You must not drive your vehicle at a speed greater than:
questions.answerB: A speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent.
questions.answerC: A speed that is safe for existing conditions.
questions.explanation: You must not drive at a speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent. You must drive at a speed that is appropriate for the area where you are driving, the type and condition of surrounding traffic, the presence of pedestrians, the weather, the quality of the road, and light conditions. You must drive within legal speed limits.

questions.question: When passing on the left of a vehicle, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
questions.answerB: When you can no longer see the vehicle over your right shoulder.
questions.answerC: When you can see the front of the vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on its left, you may move back into the right lane when the headlights of the passed vehicle can be seen in your rearview mirror. Always signal before changing lanes.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: You must bear either right or left.
questions.answerC: A four-way intersection is ahead.
questions.answerD: A road joins from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a Y intersection ahead. You must bear either to the right or to the left.

questions.question: When exiting a highway, you should slow down:
questions.answerA: On the main road, just before the exit lane.
questions.answerB: Once you see a toll booth.
questions.answerC: Once you have moved into the exit lane.
questions.answerD: When you first see the exit sign.
questions.explanation: When exiting a highway, you should get into the exit lane well in advance. Do not begin to slow down until after you have moved into the exit lane.

questions.question: If you are involved in a serious motor vehicle crash:
questions.answerB: Call the police.
questions.answerC: Determine if anyone is injured.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, move your vehicle off of the road and stop, if possible. If anyone is injured, call 911 and provide appropriate help. You must report the crash to law enforcement if there is an injury, a death, and/or more than $1,000 in property damage (or more than $200 worth of damage made to non-vehicle government property, such as signs or guardrails).

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: If you are following a school bus or tank truck, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop at all railroad crossings.
questions.explanation: School buses and tank trucks carrying flammable liquids must stop at all railroad crossings before proceeding, regardless of the presence of a train. Be prepared to stop at all railroad tracks if following one of these vehicles.

questions.question: Lanes of traffic moving in the same direction are divided by ____ lines.
questions.answerB: White
questions.answerC: Red
questions.explanation: Solid white lines are used to separate lanes traveling in the same direction (as well as to mark the right edge of the road). Broken white lines separate lanes traveling in the same direction and may be crossed to pass. Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Merging traffic.
questions.answerC: Steep hill ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers of an upcoming steep hill. Drivers should adjust their speed accordingly to avoid collisions and brake damage.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: Check your side mirror and look over your shoulder to make sure the lane is clear.
questions.answerB: Check the inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should check your side mirrors and look over your shoulder to make sure it is safe to proceed.

questions.question: When approached by an emergency vehicle that is using its siren and/or flashing lights, a driver must immediately:
questions.answerA: Pull to the right and stop.
questions.answerB: Pull to the right and slow down.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and turn on their vehicle's four-way flashers.
questions.answerD: Stop and let the emergency vehicle pass.
questions.explanation: When you are approached by an emergency vehicle that is using its lights, sirens, and/or other warning devices, you must immediately drive to the right side of the road and stop.

questions.question: If you parallel park facing downward on a hill:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels straight.
questions.explanation: When parking downhill, turn your front wheels toward the curb or edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road without a curb, turn your wheels toward the edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road with a curb, you must turn your front wheels away from the curb.

questions.question: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit in a residential area is:
questions.answerB: 35 mph.
questions.answerC: 25 mph.
questions.explanation: When driving in a residential area, the maximum speed limit is 25 miles per hour. If a different speed limit is posted, follow the posted speed limit.

questions.question: When driving on an interstate, to avoid traffic merging from on-ramps to your right, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Maintain your speed and position.
questions.explanation: When driving on an interstate highway, be aware of upcoming on-ramps. When traffic permits, move out of the right-hand lane to allow vehicles to enter from the on-ramps to your right.

questions.question: Your blind spot is the area of the road:
questions.answerA: You cannot see without moving your head.
questions.answerB: Directly behind your vehicle.
questions.answerC: You see in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: You see in your side mirror.
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas that a driver cannot see without moving their head. They can be located to the sides of and behind a vehicle.

questions.question: A large truck is ahead of you and is turning right onto a street with two lanes in each direction. The truck:
questions.answerA: May complete its turn in either of the two lanes.
questions.answerB: May have to swing wide to complete the right turn.
questions.answerC: Must stay in the right lane at all times while turning.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle makes a turn, the rear wheels follow a shorter path than the front wheels. The longer the vehicle, the bigger the difference between the paths of the front and rear wheels. Therefore, long trucks often have to swing wide to complete a right turn.

questions.question: If you’re going to turn left onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into:
questions.answerB: The lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerC: Either lane.
questions.explanation: You should always turn from the lane that is closest to the direction you want to go. Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.

questions.question: It is very foggy. You should slow down and:
questions.answerB: Turn your lights to their high beam setting.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights to their low beam setting.
questions.explanation: Use your low beams when driving in fog, snow, rain, or mist. Light from high beams will reflect off of precipitation, causing a glare and making it even more difficult to see. Some vehicles are equipped with fog lights that should be used in addition to low beam headlights.

questions.question: Adjust your rearview and side mirrors:
questions.answerB: Whenever you need to use them.
questions.answerC: Before you get into the car.
questions.explanation: Your safety and the safety of other drivers and pedestrians depends a lot on what you do before driving. Before moving your vehicle, you should adjust your seat, adjust your mirrors, fasten your safety belt, and secure items in and on your vehicle. Do not wait until your vehicle is moving to adjust your mirrors.

questions.question: Signs that are colored orange are:
questions.answerB: Regulatory signs.
questions.answerC: School zone signs.
questions.explanation: Highway work zones are established according to the type of work underway along the roadway. Signs in work areas are typically diamond-shaped, orange, have black letters or symbols, and serve as a warning that people are working on or near the highway.

questions.question: If someone has consumed alcoholic drinks, what will help the person overcome the influence of those drinks?
questions.answerB: Hot coffee
questions.answerC: Fresh air
questions.explanation: Only the passage of time will allow a person to overcome the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Driving under the influence of any medication which impairs your driving is permitted:
questions.answerB: If you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: If it is prescribed by a physician.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to drive under the influence of any substance that impairs your ability to drive safely. This includes alcohol, prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, and illegal drugs.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Hill ahead.
questions.answerC: Truck stop ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign indicates that there is a steep hill ahead. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Crossroad ahead.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming steep hill. They should adjust their speed accordingly to avoid brake damage or collision.

questions.question: When merging onto a freeway, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Proceed slowly while waiting for an opening.
questions.answerB: Accelerate to a speed that is faster than the speed of traffic.
questions.answerC: Turn on your hazard lights until safely on the freeway.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a freeway, use the on-ramp to accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic so you can blend in smoothly and safely. Entering traffic must yield to traffic already on the freeway.

questions.question: When crossing a sidewalk to enter traffic from an alley or driveway, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Stop only if pedestrians are on the sidewalk.
questions.answerB: Stop before driving onto the sidewalk or sidewalk area.
questions.answerC: Expect pedestrians on the sidewalk to yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: When leaving an alley, driveway, or parking lot to enter a roadway, you must stop before driving onto a sidewalk or sidewalk area. Pedestrians and existing traffic have the right-of-way.

questions.question: What is the meaning of this sign?
questions.answerA: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a red light.
questions.answerB: The traffic signal ahead is broken.
questions.answerC: The traffic signal ahead is displaying a green light.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal at the intersection ahead.

questions.question: Various traffic control devices in construction and maintenance work areas are the color:
questions.answerB: Orange.
questions.answerC: Yellow.
questions.explanation: Orange warning signs are used in and around work zones. Use special caution when you see orange signs, cones, or barriers on a roadway.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Hiking trails ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a school crossing is ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Highway changes ahead and to the right.
questions.answerB: Hiking trails ahead and to the right.
questions.answerC: Hotel ahead and to the right.
questions.answerD: Hospital ahead and to the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that hospital emergency services are located to the right.

questions.question: Never try to pass more than one vehicle at a time.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Never try to pass more than one vehicle at a time. Only pass another vehicle when it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow and black. This sign tells drivers that a lane is ending and that they should prepare to allow traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: What is the only effective way to remove alcohol from the body?
questions.answerB: Wait.
questions.answerC: Take a cold shower.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the effects of alcohol from the body is to let time pass. Eating, drinking coffee, or taking a shower will not speed up this process.

questions.question: A solid yellow line next to a broken yellow line means that vehicles:
questions.answerA: Driving in both directions may pass.
questions.answerB: Next to the broken line may pass.
questions.answerC: Next to the solid line may pass.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions. A broken yellow line next to your driving lane means that you may pass.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your:
questions.answerB: High beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Parking lights.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in foggy conditions, you should use your low beam headlights, as well as your fog lights, if your vehicle has them. High beams direct their light upwards, where it can bounce off the fog and into your eyes, reducing visibility even more.

questions.question: You may avoid the risks of alcohol-related crashes by:
questions.answerA: Deciding before you start drinking that you are not going to drive.
questions.answerB: Simply saying, "No thanks, I'm driving," if someone offers you a drink.
questions.answerC: Calling a taxi.
questions.explanation: The only way to avoid the risks of drinking and driving is to decide before you start drinking that you are not going to drive. Because alcohol affects your judgement, it will be harder for you to make safe decisions after you have started drinking.

questions.question: A steady yellow light at an intersection means:
questions.answerB: Yield to other cars.
questions.answerC: Slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light indicates that a steady red light will soon appear. If you are driving toward an intersection and a yellow light appears, slow down and prepare to stop. If you are already within the intersection or cannot stop safely before entering the intersection, continue through carefully.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Cars in right lane must slow down.
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: Merge.
questions.answerD: Pass only in the right lane.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates a merge ahead. It warns that two lanes of traffic moving in the same direction are about to become one.

questions.question: Excessive speed:
questions.answerA: Saves time so you can get to your destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Helps you maneuver around obstacles.
questions.answerC: Increases the likelihood of serious bodily injury and death.
questions.explanation: Excessive speed is one of the most common contributing factors to vehicle crashes. Excessive speed does not save time and often leads to high-risk decision-making.

questions.question: To see objects in their blind spot when changing lanes, drivers should check:
questions.answerB: Over their left or right shoulder.
questions.answerC: Only the inside rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's blind spots are the areas that you cannot see in your mirrors. Look over the appropriate shoulder to check your blind spot when changing lanes.

questions.question: To help prevent crashes, you should:
questions.answerB: Ignore other drivers on the road.
questions.answerC: Drive only on side streets and back roads.
questions.explanation: Crashes often happen because one driver does something that other road users are not expecting. You should communicate with other motorists, bicyclists, and pedestrians by doing things like signaling when slowing down, stopping, or changing direction. Use your emergency signals or horn when appropriate.

questions.question: Drivers may not pass a school bus when its red lights are flashing.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When approaching a school bus that is using its flashing red lights, you must stop before you reach the bus and remain stopped until the flashing lights are turned off. On a two-way multilane roadway with a median or shared center lane, vehicles on the opposite side of the road from the school bus do not have to stop.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Be ready to merge with traffic entering your lane.
questions.answerB: Always stop.
questions.answerC: Divided highway ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that merging traffic will be entering from the right, so drivers should prepare to allow the incoming traffic to safely merge.

questions.question: When you are merging onto the freeway, you should be driving:
questions.answerA: At or near the speed of traffic on the freeway.
questions.answerB: Five to 10 mph slower than the speed of traffic on the freeway.
questions.answerC: The posted speed limit for freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: When merging onto a freeway, you should enter at or near the speed of traffic.

questions.question: Alcohol is:
questions.answerB: An antihistamine.
questions.answerC: A depressant.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant that dulls your judgment and makes your reflexes unreliable.

questions.question: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you:
questions.answerA: May still turn, but you must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: May no longer turn and must proceed straight.
questions.answerC: Still have the right-of-way to turn.
questions.answerD: No longer have to turn in the direction that the arrow indicated.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you may still turn in the direction that the arrow was pointing but you must first yield to pedestrians and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: When should drivers yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in a crosswalk?
questions.answerA: Only if the pedestrians first wave to the driver.
questions.answerB: Only if the pedestrians are not texting while walking.
questions.answerC: At all times.
questions.explanation: Bring your vehicle to a complete stop at a crosswalk to yield the right-of-way to any vehicle or pedestrian already in the intersection. You may carefully proceed if your lane is completely clear.

questions.question: You come to an intersection with a flashing red light. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and drive carefully through the  intersection.
questions.answerB: Turn either right or left, since the road is blocked ahead.
questions.answerC: Stop at the intersection and wait for a flashing green light.
questions.answerD: Stop at the intersection, then proceed as traffic allows.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means that you must come to a full stop, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: If you drive more slowly than the flow of traffic, you will most likely:
questions.answerA: Interfere with traffic and receive a ticket.
questions.answerB: Improve traffic flow.
questions.answerC: Demonstrate defensive driving techniques.
questions.explanation: You must drive more slowly than usual when there is heavy traffic or bad weather. However, if you block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic by driving too slowly, you may be cited. You should match the speed of traffic, unless the speed of traffic exceeds the legal speed limit.

questions.question: A motorist making a left turn at an intersection must yield the right-of-way to a bicyclist entering the intersection from the opposite direction.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When turning left at an intersection, you must yield to oncoming bicycles in the same manner that you would yield to oncoming motor vehicles. Keep your wheels straight while waiting to turn and proceed when the way is clear of traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: Coming to a complete stop at an intersection, yielding to cross traffic/pedestrians, and then proceeding through the intersection when the way is clear corresponds with:
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light.
questions.answerC: A solid green light.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to cross traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: This sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing that does not have a signal. You should:
questions.answerB: Proceed at a consistent speed while looking and listening for approaching trains.
questions.answerC: Slow down, look both ways, listen for any trains, and be prepared to stop if any trains are nearby.
questions.explanation: At a railroad crossing marked with this sign, a driver should look both ways, listen for any trains, and be prepared to stop if any trains are nearby. Never try to outdrive an oncoming train.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign:
questions.answerA: Warns of existing or possible hazards.
questions.answerB: Alerts drivers to school zones.
questions.answerC: Alerts drivers to public recreation areas.
questions.answerD: Alerts drivers to upcoming food and gas locations.
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs warn drivers of existing or potential driving hazards. You will usually see these signs in yellow or orange.

questions.question: Before turning left, it is important to:
questions.answerB: Yield to oncoming vehicles.
questions.answerC: Swing to the right side of your lane.
questions.answerD: Wait until oncoming traffic has a red light.
questions.explanation: When turning left at a traffic signal, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: You may park no closer than ____ away from a railroad track.
questions.answerB: 40 feet
questions.answerC: 25 feet
questions.explanation: Drivers may not park within 50 feet of a railroad crossing. Only park where you will not be disruptive to traffic and where other drivers can clearly see your vehicle from every direction.

questions.question: If an officer is directing traffic at a working traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions indicated by the traffic light.
questions.answerB: Follow the directions given by the officer.
questions.answerC: Honk at the officer.
questions.answerD: Check to see what the cars next to them are doing.
questions.explanation: Traffic signals are placed at intersections to keep traffic moving and to help prevent crashes. Drivers, pedestrians, and cyclists must obey these signals, except in instances when an officer is directing traffic.

questions.question: When you see this yellow sign, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop at the crosswalk until a crossing guards signals for you to go.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop if children are in the crosswalk.
questions.explanation: A five-sided sign indicates that you are near a school. Be aware and stop if children are in the crosswalk.

questions.question: A U-turn is not permitted:
questions.answerB: On or near any curve or hill.
questions.answerC: On a straight roadway with a clear view for 500 feet in both directions.
questions.explanation: You must never turn around while on or near any curve or hill. You may not be able to see oncoming traffic or pedestrians and may cause a collision.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane shifting.
questions.answerC: Side road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a T intersection and should prepare to turn either right or left.

questions.question: If a High Intensity Activated Crosswalk signal is solid red, it means:
questions.answerB: Drivers should slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerC: Drivers should come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: HAWK signals are used at pedestrian crossings. If the signal light turns to a solid red, drivers must come to a complete stop.

questions.question: You may cross double yellow lines to pass another vehicle if the:
questions.answerA: Vehicle in front of you moves to the right to let you pass.
questions.answerB: Yellow line next to your side of the road is broken.
questions.answerC: Yellow line next to the opposite side of the road is broken.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow line in the center of the road indicates that traffic next to the broken yellow line may pass, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If your car becomes disabled while on the highway, you should:
questions.answerB: Park with all four wheels off the traveled highway, if possible.
questions.answerC: Stop where you are.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle becomes disabled, you must (if possible) park with all four wheels off of the main-traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: Regulatory signs:
questions.answerA: Are placed in every location where there is a present danger.
questions.answerB: Indicate what a driver must or must not do.
questions.answerC: Are diamond-shaped and yellow or green.
questions.answerD: May warn drivers that they are approaching a school zone.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs are often rectangular and white with black markings and are used to indicate what things a driver must or must not do in a designated area. They may display speed limits, prohibit passing or turning, or clarify any other driving regulation.

questions.question: Before changing lanes or attempting to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Check your blind spots and mirrors.
questions.answerB: Signal your intention before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Every time you want to change lanes or otherwise move your vehicle to the right or left, signal to alert other drivers to your intentions. Always check your mirrors and turn your head to check your blind spot before attempting any lateral move.

questions.question: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait until it is safe to do so, then gradually re-enter the roadway.
questions.answerB: Turn back onto the roadway immediately.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, do not attempt to turn back onto the roadway immediately. Instead, reduce your speed, check traffic, and gradually turn back onto the roadway when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You enter a designated turn lane to make a left turn at an upcoming intersection. There is oncoming traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Move to the left of the center lane.
questions.answerB: Signal before you arrive at the intersection.
questions.answerC: Turn your front wheels to the left to be prepared to turn.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you should always begin signaling about 100 feet before the turn. You should keep your front wheels aiming straight ahead until it is safe to start your turn. This ensures that you will not be pushed into oncoming traffic if another vehicle hits you from behind.

questions.question: While driving on a two-lane road without bicycle lanes, you encounter a bicyclist traveling in the same direction. What is the safest way to pass the bicyclist?
questions.answerA: Slow down and wait until there is no traffic approaching, then pass the bicyclist while leaving him or her sufficient space.
questions.answerB: Continue driving straight. It is the bicyclist’s responsibility to get out of your way.
questions.answerC: Do not pass the bicyclist until you come to a traffic signal or stop sign.
questions.answerD: Honk at the bicyclist to let him or her know you are about to pass.
questions.explanation: You should pass a bicyclist the same way you would pass any other vehicle, but not so fast or close to them that you throw debris in their face or blow them around with the draft of air from your vehicle. Allow at least 3 feet of space between your side mirror and the bicyclist, or at least 5 feet on higher speed roads or when there is a group of bicyclists. Honking unnecessarily may startle riders and make them more likely to crash.

questions.question: Which statement about speed is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Speeding can kill.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not dangerous if you are a skilled driver.
questions.answerD: Both "Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous" and "Speeding can kill."
questions.explanation: As speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases. If you are moving faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. Driving more slowly than other traffic can also be dangerous because other motorists may become impatient and make dangerous moves to pass you.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign is a:
questions.answerB: Interstate route sign.
questions.answerC: School crossing sign.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are normally diamond-shaped and yellow, although orange warning signs are used in work areas. Such signs warn that you are approaching a hazardous location or an area where special rules apply.

questions.question: How do you check your blind spots?
questions.answerA: By looking in your side mirrors
questions.answerB: By turning your head and looking over your shoulders
questions.answerC: By looking in your rearview mirror
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas around your vehicle that you cannot see by using your mirrors. Check your blind spots by turning your head and glancing over your shoulders.

questions.question: If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Not cross the tracks until the train has completely passed.
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks at your own risk.
questions.answerD: Find an alternative route across tracks.
questions.explanation: You should look and listen for trains before crossing any railroad tracks. If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you cannot go across the tracks. This is true even if they have no signals or the signals are not working.

questions.question: Orange is the color of signs used to communicate with drivers in construction work zones.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Most signs in work areas are orange and diamond-shaped, although some signs are rectangular. These signs and traffic control devices are commonly reflective to better attract your attention at night.

questions.question: You are waiting in the intersection to complete a left turn. You should:
questions.answerA: Signal and keep your wheels turned to the left.
questions.answerB: Signal and keep your wheels straight.
questions.answerC: Flash your headlights so drivers will let you through.
questions.answerD: Drive around the rear of a car if it blocks you.
questions.explanation: You must always signal before turning or changing lanes. You should keep your wheels straight while waiting to make a left turn. If another vehicle hits you from behind, this ensures that you will not be pushed into oncoming traffic.

questions.question: When driving on wet pavement, it's important to remember:
questions.answerA: That pavement is especially slippery right after it starts to rain.
questions.answerB: That wet roads can cause hydroplaning.
questions.answerC: To give yourself additional space when coming to a stop.
questions.explanation: Wet roadway surfaces can be dangerously slick, especially immediately following a rainfall. When you are driving on wet roads, your vehicle is traveling on a thin layer of oil, dirt, and water. Slow down when there is heavy rain, standing water, or slush on the road to reduce the risk of your wheels losing traction on the slick surface.

questions.question: You must pull over to the edge of the road and allow an emergency vehicle to pass:
questions.answerB: Only if it is following you.
questions.answerC: Only if it is approaching you from the opposite direction.
questions.explanation: You must pull over to the right edge of the road and stop for an emergency vehicle with flashing lights, regardless of whether it is approaching you from behind or from the opposite direction.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Watch for traffic merging from the right.
questions.answerB: Merge right.
questions.answerC: Turn left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs alert drivers to upcoming hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about potential traffic merging into their lane from the right.

questions.question: In the winter, if a road surface seems dry, it's definitely dry.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Roads that seem dry may actually be slippery and dangerous, especially during the winter. Be prepared to encounter black ice on the roadway, especially when approaching intersections, off-ramps, bridges, or shady areas.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: You must turn right.
questions.answerC: Watch for traffic on your right.
questions.answerD: Don’t park on the right side of the street.
questions.explanation: A sign with a red circle and slash over a symbol indicates that the action represented by the symbol (in this example, a right turn) is not allowed.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and keep moving in your lane.
questions.answerB: Keep driving in your lane.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right curb and stop.
questions.explanation: When you see an emergency vehicle using its lights or hear it using its siren, you must immediately pull over to the curb or side of the road and stop.

questions.question: At a light rail intersection, always:
questions.answerA: Look both ways before crossing tracks.
questions.answerB: Pay attention and obey all traffic signals.
questions.answerC: Share the road with pedestrians and bicyclists.
questions.explanation: You should never drive around lowered crossing gates. Always look both ways before turning across train tracks and always obey signs and traffic signals. Trains share the road with motor vehicles and bicyclists.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street from the wrong direction.
questions.answerB: U-turns are prohibited.
questions.answerC: You may proceed if the way is clear.
questions.explanation: This sign marks a one-way road, entrance, or exit. If you are facing this sign, traffic is coming toward you. Turn around if you are driving toward this sign.

questions.question: You should use your horn when:
questions.answerA: Another vehicle is in your way.
questions.answerB: It may help prevent a collision.
questions.answerC: Another driver makes a mistake.
